newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch call money dives ahead of quota expiry.
newsitem.headline: Dutch call money dives ahead of quota expiry.

text.p: Dutch call money rates halved on Tuesday compared to last Friday's bid price and dealers said this was due to the expiry of the current central bank credit quota this coming Friday.
Every three months the central bank sets a new quota or limit on the amount banks can borrow through its regular credit facilities at the secured loans rate.
Call money rates tend to be more volatile close to the expiry date as some participants might have used up too much of their quota or on the contrary might have saved too much.
Call money rates fell to 1.50 percent bid from 3.06 percent bid on Friday and market players expected the rate to remain low until Friday.
"Call might even drop to 1.25 percent bid," said one dealer.
Other rates were unaffected by the fall of call money rates.
Three month deposits were bid at an unchanged 3.16 percent.
The guilder was slightly stronger versus the mark, trading at 112.4325 per 100 marks from 112.46 last Friday.
